PrimaryPrelims.Title: Tribunals (Scotland) Act 2014
PrimaryPrelims.LongTitle: An Act of the Scottish Parliament to establish the First-tier Tribunal for Scotland and the Upper Tribunal for Scotland; and for connected purposes.

P2para.Text: There are established two tribunals to be known as—

P3para.Text: the First-tier Tribunal for Scotland,
the Upper Tribunal for Scotland.

P2para.Text: The Tribunals mentioned in subsection (1) are referred to in this Act—

P3para.Text: respectively as—

P4para.Text: the First-tier Tribunal,
the Upper Tribunal,

P3para.Text: collectively as the Scottish Tribunals.

P2para.Text: The constitution, operation and administration of the Scottish Tribunals are as provided for by or under this Act or another Act.
The jurisdiction, powers and other functions of the Scottish Tribunals are as conferred by or under this Act or another Act.
The Lord President is the Head of the Scottish Tribunals.
In that capacity, the Lord President has the functions exercisable by him or her by virtue of this Act.
The following persons must uphold the independence of the members of the Scottish Tribunals—

P3para.Text: the First Minister,
the Lord Advocate,
the Scottish Ministers,
members of the Scottish Parliament,
all other persons with responsibility for matters relating to—

P4para.Text: the members of the Scottish Tribunals, or
the administration of justice,

P3para.Text: where that responsibility is to be discharged only in or as regards Scotland.

P2para.Text: In particular, the First Minister, the Lord Advocate and the Scottish Ministers—

P3para.Text: must not seek to influence particular decisions of the members of the Scottish Tribunals through any special access to the members, and
must have regard to the need for the members to have the support necessary to enable them to carry out their functions.

P2para.Text: There is established the office to be known as that of President of the Scottish Tribunals.
It is for the Lord President to assign a person to that office.
An assignment of a person to that office continues for as long as the Lord President considers appropriate.
The Lord President may nominate a Vice-President of the Upper Tribunal to act temporarily in that office—

P3para.Text: if a person assigned to that office is for the time being unable to act in it, or
pending an assignment of a person to that office.

P2para.Text: A person assigned to that office under subsection (2) or nominated to act in it under subsection (4) must be a judge of the Court of Session (but may not be a temporary judge).
Under the headship of the Lord President, the President of Tribunals is the senior member of the Scottish Tribunals.
The President of Tribunals has the functions exercisable by him or her by virtue of this Act.
In this Act, a reference to the President of Tribunals is to the President of the Scottish Tribunals (and a reference to the office of President of Tribunals is to be read accordingly).

P1para.Text: The Lord President is responsible for—

P3para.Text: representing the views of the membership of the Scottish Tribunals to—

P4para.Text: the Scottish Ministers, and
the Scottish Parliament,

P3para.Text: laying before the Scottish Parliament written representations on matters that appear to the Lord President to be of importance in relation to the Scottish Tribunals (including as to the administration of justice).

P2para.Text: The Lord President is responsible for making and maintaining appropriate arrangements for securing the efficient disposal of business in the Scottish Tribunals.
The Lord President is responsible for ensuring that appropriate arrangements are made and maintained as to the welfare of the members of the Scottish Tribunals.
The Lord President may delegate to the President of Tribunals the exercise of any of the functions mentioned in subsection (2).
That is, the functions exercisable by the Lord President by virtue of—

P3para.Text: section 7(1) or (2),
section 33(1) or (2), or
section 34(1) or (2).

P2para.Text: The Lord President may give directions to the President of Tribunals as to the exercise of the functions exercisable by the President of Tribunals by virtue of this Act.
Directions under subsection (1) may—

P3para.Text: vary or revoke earlier such directions,
relate to particular functions or functions generally.

P2para.Text: Regulations under section 20(2) or 23(2) may—

P3para.Text: delegate to the Lord President authority to make arrangements of the kind to which that section relates,
include provision relying on the effect of Tribunal Rules.

P2para.Text: Regulations under section 38(1), 40(1) or 41(1) may—

P3para.Text: delegate to the President of Tribunals authority to determine the things to which that section relates,
include provision relying on the effect of Tribunal Rules.

P2para.Text: Delegation of authority under subsection (1) or (2) is subject to such provision about the exercise or sub-delegation of the authority as may be made in the regulations referred to in that subsection.
Before making regulations under section 20(2) or 23(2), the Scottish Ministers must—

P3para.Text: obtain the Lord President’s approval,
consult such other persons as they consider appropriate.

P2para.Text: Before making regulations under section 38(1), 40(1) or 41(1), the Scottish Ministers must consult the President of Tribunals.
In exercising their regulation-making functions under this Act, the Scottish Ministers must have regard to the principle below.
In exercising their leadership functions under this Act, the Lord President and the President of Tribunals must have regard to the principle below.
The principle is the need for proceedings before the Scottish Tribunals—

P3para.Text: to be accessible and fair, and
to be handled quickly and effectively.

P2para.Text: Each of the First-tier Tribunal and the Upper Tribunal is to consist of its ordinary, legal and judicial members.

Any type of member of the First-tier Tribunal or the Upper Tribunal is not, merely by reason of having that type of membership of the Tribunal, precluded from having any type of membership of the other Tribunal.
In this Act, the references to the members of the Scottish Tribunals are to—

P3para.Text: the ordinary and legal members of either or both of the Tribunals by virtue of sections 15 and 16, and
the judicial members of either or both of the Tribunals by virtue of section 17 as read with section 19.

P2para.Text: Membership of the Scottish Tribunals as an ordinary or legal member of the Tribunals has the effect of granting such a member judicial status and capacity for the purpose for which this section makes provision.
For avoidance of doubt—

P3para.Text: a judicial member of the Scottish Tribunals has judicial status and capacity for the purpose for which this section makes provision by reason of holding judicial office,
an extra judge derives judicial status and capacity in relation to the Upper Tribunal for the purpose for which this section makes provision from authorisation to act as mentioned in section 18(4).

P2para.Text: This section makes provision—

P3para.Text: in the case of an ordinary, legal or judicial member of the Scottish Tribunals, for the purpose of holding the position of and acting as such a member,
in the case of an extra judge of the Upper Tribunal, for the purpose of holding that position and acting as mentioned in section 18(4).

P2para.Text: A person is an ordinary member of the First-tier Tribunal if the person is that type of member of the First-tier Tribunal through—

P3para.Text: transfer-in as such by virtue of section 29(b), or
appointment as such by virtue of section 32(1).

P2para.Text: A person is a legal member of the First-tier Tribunal if the person is—

P3para.Text: that type of member of the First-tier Tribunal through—

P4para.Text: transfer-in as such by virtue of section 29(b), or
appointment as such by virtue of section 32(1), or

P3para.Text: however holding the position, a Chamber President or Deputy Chamber President in the First-tier Tribunal.

P2para.Text: Despite subsection (2)(b), a person assigned as a Temporary Chamber President in the First-tier Tribunal, if a judicial member of the Tribunal, remains such a member of the Tribunal.
A person is an ordinary member of the Upper Tribunal if the person is that type of member of the Upper Tribunal through—

P3para.Text: transfer-in as such by virtue of section 29(b), or
appointment as such by virtue of section 32(3).

P2para.Text: A person is a legal member of the Upper Tribunal if the person is—

P3para.Text: that type of member of the Upper Tribunal through—

P4para.Text: transfer-in as such by virtue of section 29(b), or
appointment as such by virtue of section 32(3),

P3para.Text: however holding the position, a Chamber President in the First-tier Tribunal except a Temporary Chamber President, or
however holding the position, a Vice-President of the Upper Tribunal.

P2para.Text: Despite subsection (2)(c)—

P3para.Text: a person assigned as a Vice-President of the Upper Tribunal under section 25(1) or (2) remains a judicial member of the Tribunal,
a person assigned as a Temporary Vice-President of the Upper Tribunal, if a judicial member of the Tribunal, remains such a member of the Tribunal.

P2para.Text: By reason of holding judicial office, a person is eligible to act as a member of the First-tier Tribunal if the person is a sheriff (including a part-time sheriff).
By reason of holding judicial office, a person is eligible to act as a member of the Upper Tribunal if the person is—

P3para.Text: apart from the Lord President and the President of Tribunals, a judge of the Court of Session (including a temporary judge),
the Chairman of the Scottish Land Court, or
a sheriff (except a part-time sheriff).

P2para.Text: A sheriff may act as a member of—

P3para.Text: the First-tier Tribunal, or
the Upper Tribunal,

P2para.Text: only if authorised to do so by the President of Tribunals.

A judge of the Court of Session or the Chairman of the Scottish Land Court may act as a member of the Upper Tribunal only if authorised to do so by the President of Tribunals (but see next instead for the Lord President and the President of Tribunals).

By reason of holding office within the Scottish Tribunals, each of the Lord President and the President of Tribunals is a member of the Upper Tribunal and needs no further authorisation to act as such.
An authorisation for the purpose of subsection (3)(a) or (b) or (4)—

P3para.Text: requires—

P4para.Text: the Lord President’s approval (including as to the person to be authorised), and
the agreement of the person concerned,

P3para.Text: in the case of a sheriff (apart from a sheriff principal), also requires the concurrence of the relevant sheriff principal.

P2para.Text: An authorisation for the purpose of subsection (3)(a) or (b) or (4) remains in effect until such time as the President of Tribunals may determine (with the same approval, agreement and concurrence as is referred to in subsection (6)).

If requested to do so by the President of Tribunals, the Scottish Ministers may issue a temporary authorisation for a person falling within subsection (2) to assist in the disposal of the business of the Upper Tribunal.
A person falls within this subsection if the person is—

P3para.Text: a former—

P4para.Text: judge of the Court of Session (including temporary judge),
Chairman of the Scottish Land Court, or
sheriff (except part-time sheriff), or

P3para.Text: a judge of a court or tribunal in a country or territory outwith Scotland (whether or not another part of the United Kingdom).

P2para.Text: Any request for the purpose of subsection (1) may not be made without—

P3para.Text: the Lord President’s approval, and
the agreement of the person concerned.

P2para.Text: An authorisation under subsection (1) is for the person concerned to act as if a judicial member of the Upper Tribunal during the period for which it is issued.
The period mentioned in subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: requires the same approval and agreement as is referred to in subsection (3), and
may be extended by the Scottish Ministers (with such approval and agreement).

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers may make payments of sums with respect to any time spent by a person while acting as mentioned in subsection (4) by virtue of authorisation under subsection (1).
An authorisation under subsection (1) may not be issued if the person concerned—

P3para.Text: is aged 75 years or over, or

has been removed from judicial office because of unfitness by reason of inability, neglect of duty or misbehaviour (or is for the time being suspended from such office in connection with an investigation into the question of such unfitness).

P2para.Text: In the case of a person mentioned in subsection (2)(b)—

P3para.Text: subsections (1) and (5) are subject to such further arrangements as the Scottish Ministers may make with a governmental or other body in the person’s country or territory for the purposes of those subsections,
if the person has not previously taken the required oaths, the person must take them in the presence of the President of Tribunals before acting as mentioned in subsection (4).

P2para.Text: In addition—

P3para.Text: the previous taking by a person of the required oaths counts (so far as necessary) as if it were the taking of them in connection with acting as mentioned in subsection (4),
section 3 applies in relation to a person who is authorised to act as mentioned in subsection (4)—

P4para.Text: as it does in relation to the members of the Scottish Tribunals, and
during the period for which the relevant authorisation is issued.

P2para.Text: In this section, “the required oaths” means the oath of allegiance and the judicial oath as set out in the Promissory Oaths Act 1868.
In this Act, a reference to a judicial member of the First-tier Tribunal is to a sheriff who is authorised for the purpose of section 17(3)(a).
In this Act, a reference to a judicial member of the Upper Tribunal is to—

P3para.Text: the Lord President or the President of Tribunals, or
a person who is authorised for the purpose of section 17(3)(b) or (4).

P2para.Text: A reference in this Act to a judicial member of the Upper Tribunal does not include an extra judge even where authorised to act as mentioned in section 18(4).
In this Act, a reference to an extra judge in relation to the Upper Tribunal is to a person falling within section 18(2) (as read with section 18(4)).
The First-tier Tribunal is to be organised into a number of chambers, having regard to—

P3para.Text: the different subject-matters falling within the Tribunal’s jurisdiction, and
any other factors relevant in relation to the exercise of the Tribunal’s functions.

P2para.Text: Accordingly, the Scottish Ministers may by regulations make provision for and in connection with—

P3para.Text: the organisation of the Tribunal as required by subsection (1),
the allocation of the Tribunal’s functions between the chambers.

P2para.Text: Each chamber of the First-tier Tribunal is to have—

P3para.Text: a single Chamber President to preside over the chamber, or
two Chamber Presidents to preside over the chamber.

P2para.Text: A Chamber President may not preside over more than one chamber of the Tribunal at the same time.
In this Act—

P3para.Text: a reference to a Chamber President in the First-tier Tribunal is to a Chamber President of a chamber of the Tribunal,
where a chamber of the Tribunal has two Chamber Presidents, a reference to a Chamber President of such a chamber is to either or both of them (as the context requires).

P2para.Text: It is for the Scottish Ministers to make an appointment of a Chamber President to that position.
Before making an appointment under subsection (1), the Scottish Ministers must consult the Lord President (including as to the person to be appointed).
A person is eligible for appointment under subsection (1) only if the person is—

P3para.Text: a legal member of the Upper Tribunal, or
if not falling within paragraph (a), eligible to be appointed as such a member of the Tribunal (whether or not already any type of member of the First-tier or Upper Tribunal).

P2para.Text: An appointment made under subsection (1) is for the Chamber President to preside over a particular chamber of the Tribunal.
The Upper Tribunal is to be organised into a number of divisions, having regard to—

P3para.Text: the different subject-matters falling within the Tribunal’s jurisdiction, and
any other factors relevant in relation to the exercise of the Tribunal’s functions.

P2para.Text: Accordingly, the Scottish Ministers may by regulations make provision for and in connection with—

P3para.Text: the organisation of the Tribunal as required by subsection (1),
the allocation of the Tribunal’s functions between the divisions.

P2para.Text: Each division of the Upper Tribunal is to have—

P3para.Text: a single Vice-President to preside over the division, or
two Vice-Presidents to preside over the division.

P2para.Text: A Vice-President may not preside over more than one division of the Tribunal at the same time.
Subsections (1) and (2) are subject to section 25(1)(b).
In this Act—

P3para.Text: a reference to a Vice-President of the Upper Tribunal is to a Vice-President of a division of the Tribunal,
where a division of the Tribunal has two Vice-Presidents, a reference to a Vice-President of such a division is to either or both of them (as the context requires).

P2para.Text: The President of Tribunals may assign himself or herself—

P3para.Text: as a Vice-President of the Upper Tribunal,
to preside over one or more than one division of the Tribunal.

P2para.Text: Apart from the Lord President, any other judicial member of the Upper Tribunal may be assigned by the President of Tribunals—

P3para.Text: as a Vice-President of the Tribunal,
to preside over a particular division of the Tribunal.

P2para.Text: Assignment under subsection (1)—

P3para.Text: remains in effect until such time as the President of Tribunals may determine,
does not affect the exercise by the President of Tribunals of the functions arising in that capacity.

P2para.Text: Assignment under subsection (2)—

P3para.Text: requires—

P4para.Text: the Lord President’s approval (including as to the judicial member to be assigned),
the assignee’s agreement,

P3para.Text: remains in effect until such time as the President of Tribunals may determine (with such approval and agreement),
does not affect the exercise by the assignee of any other functions as respects the Scottish Tribunals.

P2para.Text: If requested to do so by the President of Tribunals, the Scottish Ministers may appoint a person as a Vice-President of the Upper Tribunal.
Before making an appointment under subsection (1), the Scottish Ministers must consult the Lord President (including as to the person to be appointed).
A person is eligible for appointment as a Vice-President only if the person is—

P3para.Text: a legal member of the Upper Tribunal, or
if not falling within paragraph (a), eligible to be appointed as such a member of the Tribunal (whether or not already any type of member of the First-tier or Upper Tribunal).

P2para.Text: An appointment made under subsection (1) is for the Vice-President to preside over a particular division of the Tribunal.

P1para.Text: In relation to certain Housing and other Acts—

P3para.Text: a private rented housing committee,
a homeowner housing committee

P1para.Text: The Mental Health Tribunal for Scotland
In relation to the National Health Service—

P3para.Text: the NHS National Appeal Panel,
the NHS Tribunal

P1para.Text: The operation of section 28(1) and (2) is informed by and subject to the further specification in paragraph 13 (and the entries above are to be construed accordingly).

P2para.Text: The entry in paragraph 1 relates to the functions exercisable by any of the Additional Support Needs Tribunals for Scotland by virtue of section 17(1A) of the Education (Additional Support for Learning) (Scotland) Act 2004.
The entry in paragraph 2 relates to the functions exercisable by a Scottish Charity Appeals Panel by virtue of section 75(1) of the Charities and Trustee Investment (Scotland) Act 2005.

The entry in paragraph 3 relates to the functions exercisable by the Crofting Commission by virtue of the Crofters (Scotland) Act 1993 or any other enactment, but only in so far as they are decision-making functions exercisable—

P3para.Text: in the manner of a tribunal, and
with respect to the determination or resolution of disputes.

P2para.Text: The entry in paragraph 4 relates to the functions exercisable by an education appeal committee set up under section 28D(1) of the Education (Scotland) Act 1980.
In the entry in paragraph 5—

P3para.Text: paragraph (a) relates to the functions exercisable by a private rented housing committee by virtue of section 21(3) of the Housing (Scotland) Act 2006,
paragraph (b) relates to the functions exercisable by a homeowner housing committee by virtue of section 16(1) of the Property Factors (Scotland) Act 2011.

P2para.Text: The entry in paragraph 6 relates to the functions exercisable by the Lands Tribunal for Scotland by virtue of the Lands Tribunal Act 1949 or any other enactment.
The entry in paragraph 7 relates to the functions exercisable by the Mental Health Tribunal for Scotland by virtue of section 21(2) of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003.
In the entry in paragraph 8—

P3para.Text: paragraph (a) relates to the functions exercisable by the NHS National Appeal Panel or its chair by virtue of paragraph 5(4) to (6) in Schedule 3 to the National Health Service (Pharmaceutical Services) (Scotland) Regulations 2009 (S.S.I. 2009/183),
paragraph (b) relates to the functions exercisable by the NHS Tribunal by virtue of sections 29 to 32E of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978.

P2para.Text: The entry in paragraph 9 relates to the functions exercisable by a parking adjudicator by virtue of sections 72(2) and 73(3) of the Road Traffic Act 1991.
The entry in paragraph 10 relates to the functions exercisable by a police appeals tribunal by virtue of section 56(3) of the Police and Fire Reform (Scotland) Act 2012.
The entry in paragraph 11 relates to the functions exercisable by a valuation appeal committee by virtue of section 29(1)(a) of the Local Government etc. (Scotland) Act 1994.

The Scottish Ministers may by regulations provide for some or all of the transferable persons to become the holders of any of the particular or other positions within the Scottish Tribunals specified in paragraph 4(1) or (2).
In sub-paragraph (1), the transferable persons are the persons who—

P3para.Text: are members—

P4para.Text: of any of the listed tribunals, or
of any panel or other body from which the members of any of the listed tribunals are drawn,

P3para.Text: are authorised decision-makers for any of the listed tribunals, or
by reason of holding particular offices, constitute any of the listed tribunals.

P2para.Text: But sub-paragraph (2) does not apply in relation to—

P3para.Text: any—

P4para.Text: judges of the Court of Session, or
sheriffs, or

P3para.Text: if appointed by reason of holding judicial office, the President of the Lands Tribunal for Scotland.

P1para.Text: Subject to the relevant provisions of schedule 7, regulations under paragraph 1(1) may contain provision for the terms and conditions under which the persons concerned are to hold those positions, including by—

P3para.Text: preserving or altering the terms and conditions under which they are members of a listed tribunal, or
replacing those terms and conditions with new ones.

P2para.Text: Regulations under paragraph 1(1) may be made only where some or all functions of the tribunal have been, or are to be, transferred by regulations under section 28(2) (whenever made).

Regulations under paragraph 1(1) must not cause any of the persons concerned to become the holder of any particular or other position to which the person would not be eligible for appointment under the relevant provisions of schedules 3 to 6.
A particular instrument containing regulations under paragraph 1(1) may not relate to the members of more than one of the listed tribunals.
In relation to the First-tier Tribunal—

P3para.Text: the particular positions are—

P4para.Text: Chamber President in the Tribunal,
Deputy Chamber President in the Tribunal,

P3para.Text: the other positions are—

P4para.Text: ordinary member of the Tribunal,
legal member of the Tribunal (apart from Chamber President (or Deputy)).

P2para.Text: In relation to the Upper Tribunal—

P3para.Text: the particular position is Vice-President of the Tribunal,
the other positions are—

P4para.Text: ordinary member of the Tribunal,
legal member of the Tribunal (apart from Vice-President).
